lines.text: Once upon a time, long long ago...
Funny, nothing ever happens nowadays.
No longer was the valley happy, for without the magic of the harp, all was misery, misery, misery.
Just like the eighth grade.

[singing]
Don't cross a bridge or peak 'round the corner until you're there. / Just learn to smile, and in a while, you'll find trouble's a bubble of air.
Now, some folks like the heavy stuff with titles five feet wide. Not me, I'm always out for fun. I like the lighter side, yes, sir!
Life is a song - happy, gay. So let's have some music. Come on! What do you say?
This is the story of three bears.
Yeah, I know. The mama bear, the papa bear, and the itsy-bitsy baby bear.
Oh, but it's not the story you expect.
Naturally, you'd think he'd be handled with kid gloves, treated like a king, and pampered like a baby. But, no! He was tossed around like an old shoe. Bongo, the bear in the gilded cage.
Three is a crowd, they say, so I'll drop back another day.
Now, Luana, how would you like another piece of cake or some ice cream?
No, thank you. I'm full up.
Some candy?
Care for a cigar?
Me?
[everyone laughs]
How about you, Mortimer?
Uh... I don't smoke.
I don't mean that.
If it were one man and three beans... But, no. One bean and three men.
Well, at least there are no bones in it.

[referring to giant footprints]
Oh, gosh! Who made them?
Well, it wasn't Cinderella.

[pointing at one of the lines on his hand]
But what's this here? What is it? What is it?
Uh-oh! I can't believe it!
Is it bad?
Why, i-i-it says here that you can change yourself into anything!
Sure, sure! You wanna see me? I can change myself into the darndest things! Go on, gimme somethin'. Anything!
Anything?
Anything!
See? Mickey never misses a trick. He's got a good idea.
Well, uh. Can you change into a fly?
A cute, teeny-weeny, itsy-bitsy housefly?
That's it! A housefly!
Aww, you don't want a fly! How about a bunny with long, pink ears?
Huh! Well, of course, if you can't do a fly, why, uh...
All right. A fly.
[suddenly loudly]
WHY?
Well, uh... because.
Okay. A teeny-weeny fly... with pink wings! Now for the magic wordies. Fe, fi, fo, fum. He, hi, ho, hum. I'm a most amazing guy. Te, ti, te, ti, te, ti.
[transforms into a bunny]
You sure you don't want a pink bunny?
[notices that Mickey, Donald and Goofy have a fly swatter]
Hey, what is this? You think you fool Willie.
Fee, Fi, Fo, Fum... I smell...
You're telling us.
Well, Donald may be nuts, but he's got the right idea. Kill the cow.
Oh, no, Charlie! The cow was their best friend.
Well, a friend in need is a friend indeed.
So what?
So, they need some steak.
No! If you're gonna kill the cow, I don't wanna hear the rest of the story!
To think that this was once Happy Valley.
Now it's Gruesome Gulch.
Days pass, weeks pass.
I pass. You deal.
But why did the giant want to steal the harp?
Because he was cruel and selfish. He didn't care what happened to the valley. He just wanted someone to sing him to sleep.
Well, why didn't he turn on the radio?
Well, they didn't have radios in those days.
Yeah. That's why they called it Happy Valley.
[Mickey is pressed between a wall and the giant's jewelry box]
Anybody wanna buy a tall, thin mouse?
No, thank you. Uh, I mean, no.
Things look pretty dark for our heroes.
Looks like their goose is cooked.
No. There's still a chance. Don't forget, there's still the magic harp. She knows the giant's weakness.
She could be my weakness.
Yes, the voice of this golden harp cast a magic spell of joy and prosperity over the valley, but it was too good to last.
I knew there was a catch in it.
For one day...
They built a school house.
No, no.
What happened to all the people?
Well, suppose we look in on these humble peasants.
Is that a peasant?
That's a cow, stupid.
Well, at least they had milk.
Well, she used to be a good milker, but now...
She's an udder failure.
Are you listening, Mortimer?
Uh... Happy Valley?
That's right, yes. Now, just try to imagine it. Can't you just close your eyes and see it?
Well, I can't see very good with my eyes closed. My eyelids get in the way.
Well, you create a picture in your mind's eye.
Oh.
That's not easy for him. His mind gets in the way.
Pot roast! Chocolate pot roast, with stispacio... with dismashnee... with dismash... with green gravy.

[Goofy's pants have fallen down]
Ha! Caught with his pants...

[sternly]
Charlie.
Caught with his pants...
Charlie!
Well, his slip was showing.

[lifts the roof off of Edgar Bergen's house]
Hey, has anybody seen anything of a teensy-weensy, little mouse?
No, I-I-I...
[faints]
Oh, Mr. Bergen!
Bergen, speak to me! Speak to me!
What's the matter with him? Something he ate?
No, it's uh, it's a fig... fig... figmentation of his imagination.
No!
Yeah. Well, good night, Willie. Don't slam the roof. You might wake Mr. Bergen.
[laughs]
Well, what shall we do now? Any suggestions?
How would you like to go down to the city dump and watch me slug rats?
Certainly not. How would you like to hear me tell a story?
Oh, I'd love it. Wouldn't you, Charlie?
Well, I, uh... no.
This is a story that everyone should know.
Yes, but not everyone should tell it, and you know who.
I'm going to tell it anyway. Now, many, many years ago...
I think I'll go out and wind the sundial.
[tries to get up and leave, but Bergen stops him]
You'll stay right here.
What did the giant look like?
Well, he was, oh... I'll try and show you.
[He turns on a lamp and aims it at the wall]
He looked something like this.
[Makes a shadow puppet of a pig]
Looks like my pig, Snedly.
Never mind the self-portraits.
Well, no, that isn't right. He looked more like... More like this.
[Makes shadow puppet of Willie the Giant]
There he is now. And the giant came home for dinner, roaring...

[Steps in front of spotlight]
... drunk.

[as Willie]
I was not!

[Normal]
I mean, he was not.

[as Willie]
No.
Down the castle hall he came, roaring..."Fee! Fi! Fo! Fum!"
Now it was called Happy Valley because everyone who lived there was happy.
No! Well, there's a hunk of logic for you.
What mystery lurked within those cold, forbidding walls? What strange spell hovered over this gloomy place?
[Mickey knocks on door]
Will no one answer? Are they walking into a trap? Do they go in?
You know, you could stand some rehersal on this story.

[Mortimer is crying because Willie got killed]
What I'm trying to explain, Mortimer, is that Willie the Giant didn't actually exist.
No?
No. He's a metaphysical phenomenon of your subconscious mind, a phantasmagoria of your mental faculties.
Yeah?
In other words, just a figment of your imagination.
No!
Yes. So there's nothing to be upset about.

[singing]
Fe, fi, fo, fum / He, hi, ho, hum / I'm a most amazing guy / A most amazing guy am I! / Fe, fi, fo, fum / He, hi, ho, hum / I'm the stuff, I'm telling you! / For here's what I can do / I can change myself into an elf / Fly up high like the birdies / I can disappear into atmosphere - Peekaboo! / 'Cuz I know the magic wordies / Fi, fo, fe, foy / Fe, fe, fe, fe... Fi-Fi? I don't know no Fi-Fi!

[reading in a newspaper]
Here, just look at the morning paper. Turn to any page. You'll find the whole world worryin' about some future age. But why get so excited? What's gonna be is gonna be. The end of the world's been comin' since 1903. That's, uh, B.C., of course.

[comes across an envelope]
Miss Luana Patten?
[walks off]
Hmm, well! Of course, it's not cricket to read other folk's mail, but...
[stops in his tracks and sees an invitation]
A party?
[opens and reads]
"Tonight! The house across the street. Charlie McCarthy, Mortimer Snerd, Edgar Bergen." Hmm. Never heard of him. "Please come." Why, I'd be delighted!
Isn't that a wonderful trick?
Yes, indeed. Yes. I wish I could enjoy my first childhood as much as he enjoys his second.
How'd you get here?
I was kidnapped by that wicked giant!
Oh. What? A giant?
A giant?
A giant?
A giant?
Bigger than forty men!
Oh, no!
An ogre who had the power to turn himself into anything, man or beast!
That calls for a drink!
[Mickey has retrieved the key to the jewel box from Willie's pocket and has climbed back up to the box]
He made it!
He did?
[looks through keyhole]
Here he comes with the key!

[looking through keyhole]
Let me have it, Mickey!
[the key goes through the keyhole and hits Donald, knocking him over]

[talking about Bongo]
He was a circus bear. He was born in the circus, grew up in the circus, in fact, Bongo was the star of the circus. Why, he could juggle and dance while on a trapeze; walk a tightrope with the greatest of ease. In jujitsu, he was beyond compare; once threw a bull at the county fair; super at wrestling and lifting weights; outboxed the champs of seventeen states. They all packed in from near and far to see this death-defying star. With mouths wide open, they watched his ascent as he daringly climbed to the top of the tent. Then for a grand climax, he would gracefully plunge three hundred feet into a wet sponge.
The fields of golden corn turned to dust.
Kerplop.
The laughing brook flowed no more. To think that this was once Happy Valley!
Now it's Gruesome Gulch.
Well, good night, Luana.
Good night, Ophelia.
Bonne nuit, Mortimer.
Uh... ma'am?
Bonne nuit.
Oh, yes, ma'am. Yeah, yeah. Bunny. Uh bunny, bunny wee, bunny wee. Bun-Uh... uh, I don't know no bunny wee.
You know, you worry too much. In fact, everybody worries too much.
Never saw such a dismal pair. A deadpan doll and a droopy bear.
Naught left but beans.
Ahem. Bean, you mean.

[singing]
Lots of starches, / Lots of greens, / Fancy chocolate-covered...
Beans!
What d'you mean, "beans"?
Yeah, fellows. I sold the cow for some magic beans!
Beans?
[goes crazy]
But Donald! These are not ordinary beans! They're magic beans! If you plant these beans in the light of a full moon, do you know what'll happen?
Yes! We get more beans!
[Willie is sniffing around his table while Mickey and the others are trying to avoid getting caught]
Hey, giant! You're getting warm!
Well, don't tell him!
Behind the jar, stupid!
Charlie!

[as the beanstalk climbs into the stratosphere]
And all through the night, it grew onward and upward.
That thing is a menace to aviation.
Just look at that miserable creature. Doggedly struggling to maintain life. A gaunt, lean bag of bones and feathers. Truly a picture of despair. But Donald doesn't whimper. Donald doesn't give up.
Shut up! I can't stand it!

[wearing a mustache; growling]
I'm a giant!
You are not. You're nothing of the kind.
Well, I'm a small giant.
No, you're not!
I'm, uh... I'm tougher than forty men!
You're not.
Well, er... twenty men.
No.
No? Ten men?
Aren't you ashamed of yourself, Charlie? Why do you act like that?
I don't know. I guess it's just a stage I'm going through.
Well, take off that mustache.
[pulls mustache off Charlie's face]
Ow!
Now go over there and behave yourself!
Yes, sir. Everything I do is wrong.

[singing to the tune of "Funiculi Finicula"]
Turkey, lobster, sweet potater pie/ pancakes piled up til they reach the sky

[scat singing]
Wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak wak!
Ooooooooooh!
[his Adam's apple knocks out Donald]
I'm gonna eat and eat, and eat and eat, and eat until I die!

[both singing]
Turkey, lobster, sweet potato pie/ pancakes piled up til they reach the sky

[singing]
Lots of scorches, lots of leaves, some fancy chocolate covered -...
Beans!

[disgusted]
What do you mean beans?
Yeah fellas I sold the cow for some nice beans
Beans?
[jumps into the ceiling throwing a temper tantrum while tearing out his head feathers]
But Donald these are no ordinary beans they're magic beans, if you plant these beans on the night of a full moon do you know what'll happen?
Yes you'll get more beans!
[takes the box from him and throws them into a hole in the floor]
No, no, Donald!
Magic beans!, phooey!
Ooh, dragonflies!
Yeah. A-flyin' front and draggin' behind.
[Willie prepares himself a sandwich]
Feedee!
[Slices some cheese, taking Mickey but narrowly avoiding Goofy]
Fidee!
[Takes a chicken leg]
Fodee!
[Takes some onions, narrowly missing Donald]
Fum!
[Pours pepper on his sandwich. Mickey sneezes the contents on Willie's face]
Gesundheit!
[laughs]
Yes, it was one of nature's garden spots, nestled among the green, rolling hills. Can't you see the lovely brook as it flows through the valley?
Mmm. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
The winding roads, line with stately trees.
Trees. Yeah.
Lush fields and prosperous farms dot the landscape.
L-Landscape. Yeah.
And high on a hilltop overlooking the valley, shining like a jewel, stands...
My red barn.
No, no. It was something much nicer. It was a majestic castle.

[flying toward a scarecrow, then dancing on one of his arms]
Never knew such bliss, never read of this in a book or plaaaaaay, what a lovely daaaaaay! What a great big gorgeous, sumptious, thumping, bumptious, hum-galumptious, simply scruptious!
[all fall off the scarecrow's arm, then fly vertically above then back down to the scarecrow's arm]
Oh my, oh my, what a haaaaap-py daaaaaay!
[all laugh]
